pull.title: key.cpp: fail with a friendlier message on missing ssl EC support
pull.body: Previously if bitcoind is linked with an OpenSSL which is compiled without EC support, this is seen as an assertion failure "pKey != NULL" at key.cpp:134. It is an esoteric piece of knowledge to interpret this as "oops, I linked with the wrong OpenSSL".

events.body: Thanks Luke, I didn't know about abort. Fixed.

Thanks for the suggestion, @luke-jr. I've updated the PR to use uiInterface.ThreadSafeMessageBox which is the logging function used for other failures in init.cpp, and also added a URL to a wiki page describing the problem and available workarounds.

Instead of deferring this to the last moment and create a dependency of the key.c/h on UI interface, I'd prefer adding this check (and potentially other sanity checks, see #4081) earlier in the init sequence, for example in AppInit2 before any key objects are instantiated.

verification.payload:
tree 52a07bc8e7880c7ff0b7bec11083926b7bdd64f4
parent 52d7a544342b20fbf0d8b97796923455a400d282
author Andrew Poelstra <asp11@sfu.ca> 1401751263 -0700
committer Andrew Poelstra <asp11@sfu.ca> 1401822591 -0700

key.cpp: fail with a friendlier message on missing ssl EC support

Previously if bitcoind is linked with an OpenSSL which is compiled
without EC support, this is seen as an assertion failure "pKey !=
NULL" at key.cpp:134, which occurs after several seconds. It is an
esoteric piece of knowledge to interpret this as "oops, I linked
with the wrong OpenSSL", and because of the delay it may not even
be noticed.

The new output is

: OpenSSL appears to lack support for elliptic curve cryptography. For
more information, visit
https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/OpenSSL_and_EC_Libraries
: Initialization sanity check failed. Bitcoin Core is shutting down.

which occurs immediately after attempted startup.

This also blocks in an InitSanityCheck() function which currently only
checks for EC support but should eventually do more. See #4081.

events.message:
key.cpp: fail with a friendlier message on missing ssl EC support

Previously if bitcoind is linked with an OpenSSL which is compiled
without EC support, this is seen as an assertion failure "pKey !=
NULL" at key.cpp:134, which occurs after several seconds. It is an
esoteric piece of knowledge to interpret this as "oops, I linked
with the wrong OpenSSL", and because of the delay it may not even
be noticed.

The new output is

: OpenSSL appears to lack support for elliptic curve cryptography. For
more information, visit
https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/OpenSSL_and_EC_Libraries
: Initialization sanity check failed. Bitcoin Core is shutting down.

which occurs immediately after attempted startup.

This also blocks in an InitSanityCheck() function which currently only
checks for EC support but should eventually do more. See #4081.

events.body: Ok, I've refreshed the PR; I left the assertion in place and added an InitSanityCheck function to init.cpp which does the check. The failure is now both clean and immediate (the old assertion failure took several seconds to trigger on my machine). The function InitSanityCheck is also a clear place to add the additional checks suggested in #4081.

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/4a09e1df51267c6d2dec219c6f96a24b716cc251 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
Oh, I should probably mention that I've tested this (and every candidate along the way) with a good and bad OpenSSL library. It works correctly in both cases.
Code changes look good to me.

comments.body: Should probably use the logging functions... Maybe explain a bit about how the user may consider solving it?
